Hawaiian: A ko'olau wau ike I ka ua
E ko-kolo la-lepo mai ana e ka ua
E ka'i ku ana mai ana e ka ua
E nu mai ana e ka ua I ke kuahiwi
E po'i ana e ka ua me he nalu ala
E puka, e puka mai ana e ka ua
Waliwali ke one i ka hehi'a e ka ua
Aia ka wai la I ka ilina, he ilio
He ilio hae, ke nahu nei e puka
English: At Ko'olau I greeted the rain
The rains creeping and tossing the dust
LINEBREAK
Dancing in columns, the rains appear
Roaring rains through the mountains
LINEBREAK
The crest of the rains, break like the waves
An opening through which the rains appear
LINEBREAK
Pasty comes the earth from the stamping rains
Filling the streams with a rushing flood
The mountain walls leap with the rain
LINEBREAK
See the water chafing its bounds like a dog
A raging dog, gnawing its way to pass out

title: A'ia La O Pele I Hawai'i
notes: The traditional, chanted version of "Aia lā 'o Pele" belongs to the collection of Joseph Keali'iakamoku 'Īlālā'ole (1873–1965), one of the "last great Hawaiian chanters to have been born in the 19th century"

Hawaiian: Ke ha'a mai lā i Maukele 'eā
Ke nome a'e lā iā Puna, 'eā
Ka mea nani ka i Paliuli 'eā
Ke pulelo a'e lā i nā pali 'eā
I hea kāua e la'i ai 'eā?
I ka 'ale nui a'e li'a nei 'eā
English: Pele is in Hawai'i
She is dancing at Maukele
She rumbles and mutters
As she consumes Puna.
Flashing in the heavens, on and on
O Pele, Pele.
LINEBREAK
The Beautiful One is at Paliuli
Rising over the cliffs
She is at the borders of Maui
Land of the chief Kaululā'au
Flashing in the heavens, on and on
O Pele, Pele.
LINEBREAK
Where will we find peace?
On the great billows we love
Blazing above, blazing below, hitching along
Pele is the woman from Kahiki
Flashing in the heavens, on and on
O Pele, Pele.
LINEBREAK
This is the end of my song
Pele is in Hawai'i
Tell again the refrain
In honor of Hi'iaka
Flashing in the heavens, on and on
O Pele, Pele.

Hawaiian: E ala e, ka lā i ka hikina,
I ka moana, ka moana hohonu,
Pi'i ka lewa, ka lewa nu'u,
I ka hikina, aia ka lā, e ala e!
English: Awaken/Arise, the sun in the east
LINEBREAK
From the ocean, the deep ocean,
LINEBREAK
Climbing to heaven, the highest heaven,
LINEBREAK
In the east, there is the sun, arise!

Hawaiian: ME NA HOE WA'A O KAMOHOALI'I
HOE KA MO'I O KE KAI x 2
HOLO AKU MAKOU I KA MOANA
'AKU 'AKU E KA IHU LA O KA WA'A
KE KOKOMO MAI LA KA WA'A
A LIKE ME KA WA'A HONUAIAKEA
LI'U KA 'IKE I KA HOLO WA'A
HOE KA KUA MO'O OLELO I NA PO'E x 2
E O E KA HUAKI'I A PELE
ME NO HOE WA'A O KAMOHOALI'I
HOE KA MO'I O KE KAI x 2
No luna ʻi ka hale kai o ka Maʻalewa
Nana ka maka i a Moananui-ka-lehua la
Noho i ke kai la maliu ē
I ku aʻela ka lehua ilaila la
Hōpoe ka lehua kiʻekiʻe i luna lā
Makaʻu ke kanaka I ka lehua
i lalo hoʻi, i lalo hoʻi
O keaʻau iliʻili nehe i ke kai la
Hoʻolono i ke kai aʻo Puna
Aʻo Puna i ka ulu hala la
kai koʻo Puna, kai koʻo Puna
He inoa no Hiʻiaka I ka poli o Pele
English: On Mount Halekai hangs the Maʻalewa
Gazing at goddess Moananui-ka-lehua
Sitting peacefully by the sea
With lehua standing there
LINEBREAK
There, indeed. There, indeed
LINEBREAK
The lehua tree of Hopoe stands majestically tall
The lehua is fearful of man
Leaving him to walk on the ground
LINEBREAK
Down below. Down below, indeed
LINEBREAK
The pebbles at Keaʻau grind in the surf
The sea of Keaʻau calls to Puna
Fierce is the sea of Puna in the Hala groves
LINEBREAK
The rough sea of Puna. The rough sea of Puna

Hawaiian: Hoʻopuka e ka lā ma ka hikina
Me ka huakaʻi hele no Kumukahi.
Haʻa mai nā ʻiwa me Hiʻiaka
Me Kapo Laka i ka uluwehiwehi.
Neʻe mai nā ʻiwa ma kuʻu alo
Me ke alo kapu o ka āiwaiwa.
Hoʻi no e ke kapu me nā aliʻi
English: Let the sun rise in the east,
Forth it goes on its journey to Kumukahi
The sea bird comes forth with Hiʻiaka,
Kapo emerges from the deep forest.
The birds draw close before me,
Before me the wonderful one.
Let the kapu go back to the chiefs
And let us all have life.
LINEBREAK
Rise, O sun in the east
With a procession going to Kumukahi
LINEBREAK
Dancing are the beautiful ones with Hiʻiaka
And Kapo-Laka in the verdant grove
LINEBREAK
Moving ahead are the dancers toward me
And to the sacred presence of the divine
LINEBREAK
Let the sacred ways return to the chiefs
Let us all give everlasting praise
LINEBREAK
Tra-la-la-la
LINEBREAK
In the name of Hiʻiaka-in-the-bosom-of Pele
